revision.text:
The '''Washington Accord''' is an international accreditation agreement for professional [[engineering]] [[academic degree]]s between the bodies responsible for accreditation in its signatory countries. Established in 1989, the full signatories as of 2018 are [[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[Taiwan]], [[Pakistan]], [[China]], [[Hong Kong]], [[India]], [[Ireland]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Malaysia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Russia]], [[Singapore]], [[South Africa]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Turkey]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Philippines]], [[Peru]] and the [[United States]].<ref name=Signatories>{{cite web| title=Washington Accord| url=http://www.ieagreements.org/accords/washington/signatories/| publisher=International Engineering Alliance|accessdate=20 April 2017}}</ref>
The agreement recognizes that there is substantial equivalence of programs accredited by those signatories. Graduates of accredited programs in any of the signatory countries are recognized by the other signatory countries as having met the academic requirements for entry to the practice of engineering. Recognition of accredited programs is not retroactive but takes effect only from the date of admission of the country to signatory status.
==Scope== The Washington Accord covers undergraduate engineering degrees under [[Outcome-based education]] approach.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.utar.edu.my/fes/file/OBE.pdf| title=Outcome Based Education| date=18 June 2008}}</ref> [[Engineering technology]] and [[postgraduate]] engineering programs are not covered by the accord. Engineering technology programs are covered under the [[Sydney Accord]] and [[Dublin Accord]]. Only qualifications awarded after the signatory country or region became part of the Washington Accord are recognized. The accord is not directly responsible for the licensing of [[Professional Engineer]]s and the registration of [[Chartered Engineer]]s, but it does cover the academic requirements that are part of the licensing processes in signatory countries.
==Signatories== The following are the signatory countries and territories of the Washington Accord, their respective accreditation bodies and years of admission:<ref name="Signatories"/> * [[Australia]] - ([[Engineers Australia]], 1989) * [[Canada]] - ([[Engineers Canada]], 1989) * [[People's Republic of China]] - ([[China Association for Science and Technology]], 2016) * [[Taiwan]] - ([[Institute of Engineering Education Taiwan]], 2007) * [[Hong Kong, China]] - ([[The Hong Kong Institution of Engineers]], 1995) * [[India]] - ([[National Board of Accreditation]], 2014)<ref>{{cite news| url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/delhi/boost-for-techies-as-ind-now-full-member-of-washington-accord_939300.html| title=Boost for techies as Ind now full member of Washington Accord| date=13 June 2014| publisher=Znews}}</ref> * [[Ireland]] - ([[Engineers Ireland]], 1989) * [[Japan]] - (Japan Accreditation Board for Engineering Education, 2005) * [[Korea]] - (Accreditation Board for Engineering Education of Korea, 2007) * [[Malaysia]] - ([[Board of Engineers Malaysia]], 2009) * [[Pakistan]] - ([[Pakistan Engineering Council]], 2017)<ref>{{cite web|last1=IEAT|first1=Alliance|title=IEAT|url=http://www.ieagreements.org/accords/washington/signatories/}}</ref> * [[New Zealand]] - ([[Engineering New Zealand]], 1989) * [[Russia]] - (Association for Engineering Education of Russia, 2012) * [[Singapore]] - (Institution of Engineers Singapore, 2006) * [[South Africa]] - ([[Engineering Council of South Africa]], 1999) * [[Sri Lanka]] - ([[Institution of Engineers, Sri Lanka]], 2014) * [[Turkey]] - (MÜDEK, 2011) * [[United Kingdom]] - ([[Engineering Council UK]], 1989) * [[United States]] - ([[ABET]], 1989) * [[Peru]] - ([[ICACIT]], 2018)
The following countries have provisional signatory status and may become member signatories in the future:<ref>{{cite web| publisher=Washington Accord| url=https://www.washingtonaccord.org/washington-accord/signatories/| title=Signatories}}</ref> * [[Bangladesh]] - (Board of Accreditation for Engineering and Technical Education) * [[Costa Rica]] - (Association of Engineers and Architects of Costa Rica) * [[Mexico]] - (Consejo de Acreditación de la Enseñanza de la Ingeniería) * [[Philippines]] - (Philippine Technological Council) * [[Chile]] - (Acredita.CI)
==See also== * [[Sydney Accord]] - engineering technologists * [[Dublin Accord]] - engineering technicians * [[Seoul Accord]] - computing and information technology * [[Outcome-based education]] * [[Chartered Engineer]] * [[Professional Engineer]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ieagreements.org/Accords/Washington International Engineering Alliance Washington Accord website]
[[Category:Professional titles and certifications]] [[Category:Engineering education]]

revision.text:
'''William Lewis Barrett''', also '''W. Lewis Barrett''', (1847–1927) was a professional [[flautist]] and [[music teacher]].
==Early life and education== Barrett was born in 4 January 1847 in [[London]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Musical Notes from Abroad: Obituary|journal=The Musical Times|volume=68|number=1009|date=March 1, 1927|pages=268–270|jstor=913361}}</ref> His parents were Mary (née Lewis) and Thomas Barrett, a violinist. His mother was from [[Dinas Mawddwy]], [[Wales]],<ref name="DWB" /> where he began his education. Barrett then was schooled in Cemmes, [[Montgomeryshire]].<ref name="Griffith" /> He learned to play the flute and violin, having studied the flute under Richard Shepherd Rockstro.<ref name="DWB">{{cite web|title=William Lewis Barrett|url=http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-BARR-LEW-1847.html|author=Robert David Griffith|year=1959|website=Dictionary of Welsh Biography|publisher=National Library of Wales|accessdate=8 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Griffith" />
==Career== He began his career as a flautist by 1868, playing for the [[Italian opera|Italian Opera]]. He later played with the [[Sacred Harmonic Society]], [[Royal Philharmonic Society]], and the [[Carl Rosa Opera Company]], having become the principal flautist. In addition to a number of performances for [[Queen Victoria]],<ref name="DWB" /><ref name="Evans">{{cite news|url=http://newspapers.library.wales/view/3433205/3433206/6/ |title=Music in Wales|author=D. Emlyn Evans|newspaper=The Cardiff Times|date=12 January 1907|page=1|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref> he performed in concerts and music festivals in the [[United Kingdom]], [[United States]], and [[Canada]].<ref name="DWB" /> D. Emlyn Evans said of his performances, "Those who have heard Mr Barrett's solo work, whether in opera or at festivals, or playing obligato to one of the queens of song on the concert platform, can well understand and endorse Queen Victoria’s appreciation of his quality of tone…"<ref name="Evans" />
Between 1883 and 1910, he taught the flute at the [[Royal College of Music]].<ref name="DWB" /><ref name="Griffith">{{cite book|author=Frederic Griffith|title=Notable Welsh Musicians (of Today): With Portraits, Biographies, and a Preface on the Condition of Music in Wales at the Present Time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oUopAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA121|year=1896|publisher=F. Goodwen|page=121}}</ref> Barrett was also a composer.<ref>{{cite book|author=Leonardo De Lorenzo|title=My Complete Story of the Flute: The Instrument, the Performer, the Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qdxENVZtDccC&pg=PA161|year=1992|publisher=Texas Tech University Press|isbn=978-0-89672-277-4|page=161}}</ref> He died in [[London]] at the [[Savage Club]] on 10 January 1927, and was buried in [[Kensal Green|Kensal Rise]] in northwest London.<ref name="DWB" />
== References == {{reflist}}
